3 ABSTRACT Research into the structure, synthesis and properties of nanoscale materials have moved at an enormous pace over the past decades as they have a really large variety of applications ranging from adsorption to separation processes in water treatment. A wide range of technologies such as adsorption, electrochemical, membrane filtration, and ionexchange methods have been productively used in water treatment and the nanoparticles also find application in each of these fields. Water pollution by various toxic contaminants such as proteins, humic acids, and oils as well as the shortage of pure water has become the most serious environmental issues encountered worldwide. Recently, nanomaterials incorporated polymeric ultrafiltration membranes have been used effectively in water treatment technologies to address these environmental issues. Herein, we concisely review the performances of membranes incorporated with a variety of nanomaterials. This review sums up some very recent results and contributions made by nanomaterials so far in the emerging field of ultrafiltration membrane technology research. Further, this review deals methods of incorporation of diverse nanomaterials and their influence in altering the membrane properties to improve performance. Special emphasis in the review has been given to hydrophilicity, mechanical and thermal stability, and the antifouling and antibacterial activity of nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Increasingly, drinking water resources are showing evidence of contamination by several kinds of pollutants like macromolecular proteins, oils, humic acids, dust particles, etc. Traditional water treatment methods do not effectively remove the contaminants which pollute water sources, and are not capable of eliminating these emerging pollutants, and not able to meet higher water quality standards.1-3 In the beginning, activated carbon which was employed for waste water purification, has been replaced more recently by more costeffective membrane technologies.4-7 Recycling as well as purification of contaminated water using membrane technology has become the most efficient and cost effective way to retain fresh water resources around the world.8-10 Among the various membrane based waste water purification technologies, ultrafiltration is considered to be one of the most important fields of interest. This technology offers excellent efficiency in the separation of pollutants using more environmentally friendly and cost effective processes when compared to the thermal separation and purification techniques which involves a high operating temperature with increased process cost.11,12 However, these membranes are damaged by organic/inorganic fouling and biofouling which reduces the membrane shelf life. Generally, fouling phenomena were caused by the interaction between the membrane surface and the foulants, which includes different forms of organic, inorganic and biological substances.13,14 The foulants not only physically interact with the membrane, but they chemically degrade the membrane by their deposition and accumulation on the surface. This affects the overall membrane performance as it causes flux decline under high pressure, rapid degradation in membranes, low tolerance to hydraulic pressure, lowered water permeability and decreased contaminant rejection.15 This leads to the frequent replacement of membranes which results in increased process cost. Therefore, it becomes essential to modify the membrane matrix to enhance fouling resistance in order to overcome the above mentioned issues.

5 An ideal membrane should provide high water flux, good mechanical and thermal resistance, high percentage rejection of contaminants, and high antifouling as well as antibiofouling properties which ensure its long shelf life. In the past decades, the field of nanotechnology has grown tremendously and has established a range of applications in almost all branches of science and technology.16-18 Furthermore, the synthesis and structural analysis of various nanoscale materials have been done extensively and employed in various fields such as electromagnetic wave absorption,19-21 water splitting,22 biosensors,23,24 foulant, dye removal,25 etc. Many interesting experimental results have also been reported in the literature regarding the tremendously fast mass transport properties exhibited by carbon nanotubes (CNTs) incorporated membranes.26,27 The CNT modified membranes have been found to possess narrowly formed pores with straight - channel morphology when perpendicularly aligned into the base membrane matrix. These membranes exhibited outstanding water permeation properties confirming the faster mass transportation mechanism.28 It is noteworthy that, other than water treatment, the polymer nanocomposite blend membranes were fabricated using different compositions of nanomaterials/polymers and employed in various fields of science and engineering because of their wide applicability and operational/material flexibility.29-32 The polymer nanocomposite membranes possess outstanding mechanical and thermal properties. Customizing the materials and mode of membrane fabrication has been widely investigated by various researchers and these have been used as support for catalysts,33 conducting materials,34 anti-adhesive/corrosive coating,35,36 anion exchange membranes,37,38 etc. In order to address the bottlenecks encountered in the membrane technology, several researchers investigated the use of two dimensional nanomaterials for water treatment and remediation.39-41 The design and development of water treatment membranes with the

That is, nanoparticle incorporation has created a novel class of mechanically and thermally strong, high-flux, high-selective, and fouling resistant nanocomposite membranes for water treatment.42,43 Major advantages of nanocomposite membranes over pristine polymeric membranes, in terms of thermal, hydraulic stability and anti-biofouling properties, were depicted in
Figures 1 and 2.41,44 Herein, we present a comprehensive review of the performance of polymeric ultrafiltration membranes, which are incorporated with carbon and metal oxide based nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 2. Nanomaterials as hydrophilic modifiers for water treatment
sections.text:
In water treatment membrane processes, various kinds of polymers have been extensively used as a base material. For instance, Forward Osmosis (FO) and Reverse Osmosis (RO) techniques use membranes that are probably made up of polyamide and cellulose triacetate polymers. Other membrane technologies such as ultra-filtration (UF), nano-filtration (NF), etc., make use of poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), poly(ether sulfone) (PES), poly(ether imide) (PEI), etc., besides techniques like capacitive de-ionization (CDI) that is employed in the separation of solutes from solvents. This is done through an electrosorption and regeneration process mainly using carbon based membranes.45 It should be noted that, whatever process is an essential, all the membranes used in such techniques are required to perform with the highest water permeability with the greatest foulant rejection. These requirements of membrane technology combined with the current advances in nano- and material- science have led to the discovery of a new research trend which involves the ‘usage of nanomaterials as hydrophilic additives in the polymeric membrane matrix’.

8 Generally, nano-additives are nano-sized particles, which can be organic or inorganic materials which can effectively perform as a hydrophilic additive for UF membranes. This additive imparts high hydrophilicity, and excellent efficiency to the membrane involved in isolating the contaminants from water through its high porosity and large active surface area. As these materials are nano-sized with a large surface area and surface area to volume ratio, they exhibit unique characteristic properties.46 Hence, to attain further improvements in water treatment, employing nanomaterials as an additive is becoming a new alternative for macromolecular pore formers for separation of contaminants.11,47 Further, incorporation of nanoparticles in the fabrication of water purification membranes is quite simple and yet effective and that is a reason why scholarly interests in the use of nanocomposite water treatment membranes have been growing rapidly worldwide.48 Since these nanomaterials have garnered growing interest in water treatment, this doesn’t mean that these materials are free from limitations. These nanomaterials do have limitations such as a high pressure requirement, and surface pore blockage when used at higher concentrations, etc.49,50 Hence, developing a cost-effective, problem free and reliable water treatment technology has become a significant challenge in the field of water purification.

sections.heading: 2.1 Dispersion of nanoparticles
sections.text:
The overall performance of the nanocomposite membranes is greatly dependent upon the size, shape, dispersity, concentration and interactions of the nanoparticles with the membranes.51 It has been especially reported in the literature that the dispersion of nanoparticles has a significant influence in modifying membrane morphology and pore characteristics.52 However, the most important bottle neck affecting nanoparticle incorporation into any substrate is that of achieving uniform distribution throughout the composite material without any agglomeration. During the fabrication of nanocomposite

9 membranes, the formation of agglomerates can lead particularly to a pore blockage in the surface and a macrovoid disconnection in bulk which decreases the overall water permeation properties of the resultant membranes.53 Generally, the low dispersity of nanoparticles in the polymer matrices happen due to two main reasons: (i) incompatibility of nanoparticles with the polymer material, and (ii) the agglomeration of nanoparticles in the membrane matrix during phase inversion at relatively higher additive concentrations.54 Further, the absence of chemical bonding between the polymer matrices with the nanoadditive also limits the dispersity and overall stability of nanoparticles in the membrane matrix.55 Hence, it becomes necessary to improve the dispersion of these particles in casting dope solutions to achieve a nanocomposite membrane with desired performance characteristics. Surface modification of nanoadditives has been proposed as an effective solution by many researchers to address this dispersity issue.56 Two popular ways have been proposed to modify the surface of nanoparticles:57 Using chemical treatment to modify the nanoparticle surface and using the functionalization method in which the functional polymeric molecules are grafted to the hydroxyl groups usually present in the nanoparticles. Karousis et al. employed a chemical functionalization method to improve the dispersion of MWCNTs in organic solvents to produce novel hybrid materials.58 In addition, organic acids can be used for the effective surface treatment of metal oxide nanoparticles since the hydroxyl sites of these nanoparticles can react with the carboxylic functional groups present in the acids thereby improving their dispersion in organic solvents.59,60 Some reports also suggested that the grafting of different surfactants such as sodium lauryl sulfate (SLS) on a nanoparticle surface can effectively mitigate the agglomeration issue by improving nanoparticle dispersion.61 Iijima et al. reported that nanoparticle dispersion stability in organic solvents can easily be improved by the adsorption of cationic/anionic polymeric dispersants on the nanoparticle surface.62 Once these dispersants get adsorbed on the nanoparticle surface, generation of steric repulsive forces

from the polymer chain result, thereby increasing the surface charge of the adsorbed
nanoparticle. As a positive consequence of this, a uniform distribution of nanoparticles in organic solvent medium can be achieved.63 Also, rather than modifying nanoparticles,
preparation of nanocomposite membranes by sol-gel method has been reported to be an
effective strategy to improve nanoadditive dispersion. This method combines the benefits of a traditional immersion precipitation technique and in-situ preparation of nanoparticles.64
Further, the nanoparticles prepared by sol-gel method have been reported to be beneficial in
minimizing nanoparticle leaching from the membranes during filtration experiments by enhancing the compatibility of nanoparticles with polymers.65 Hence, with reference to the
recent literature, by adopting suitable pre-treatments, the issue of agglomeration and leaching
of nanoparticles can be addressed. As a result, membranes with desired morphology
containing uniformly distributed nanoadditives can achieve improved water permeation
performance.

sections.heading: 2.2. Bio-toxicity of nanomaterials
sections.text:
The production of nanosized materials and their incorporation in materials design;
especially in membrane technology, is an important milestone since this imparts the desired
characteristics in the resultant nanocomposite membranes. Generally nanoparticles are
employed in water treatment membranes to improve the hydrophilicity which promotes better antifouling properties.66 Zunita et al. has done a separate review on the performance of
graphene oxide (GO) embedded membranes for gas separation and water treatment applications.67 These researchers reported that the fouling and biofouling resistance of the
membranes along with the water permeation and solute rejection properties are greatly
enhanced due to the size exclusion and electrostatic interaction characteristics of embedded
GO. Compared to micro sized hydrophilic additives, the nanoparticles find better dispersion

11
in polymer solutions and that’s why the silica/polyamide nanocomposite membranes possess
higher water permeation and foulant separation properties than native membranes as reported by Niksefat et al.68 Irrespective of the compound and its chemical properties, nanoscaled
particle incorporation can make a significant difference in overall membrane performance.
Nevertheless, to design overall best performing nanocomposite membranes, the concentration
of nanoadditives should be optimized during the fabrication process and the stability of
nanoparticles in the membrane matrix should be assured during filtration experiments. It is an
absolute necessity to think about the hazardous effects and risk factors that nanomaterials can
possibly pose to the environment should these be released from embedded nanocomposite
membranes. As the particle size of any material decreases, there will be an exponential
increase in its surface area property which means a relatively higher proportion of atoms of a nanoparticle will be presented more often on the surface than in the particle bulk.69 This
increases the reactivity of the nanoparticle with the surrounding environment leading to mammalian health risks.70 Especially in water treatment applications, there is a possibility of
leaching of nanoparticles from their respective incorporated membranes during filtration due mostly to incompatibility with the polymer.71 This phenomenon leads to an eventual decrease
in membrane performance and can cause harmful effects to the environment. Buzea et al.
reported that the unfavorable effects caused by nanoparticles in mammalian health depends to
a higher degree on the personal factors (existing health problems, genetics, etc.,) and physical and chemical properties of the nanoparticles (shape, size, reactivity, exposure time, etc.).72
Also, after inhalation when compared to larger particles, the removal of nanoscale particles
from lungs has been reported to be difficult/less efficient when employing macrophage clearance mechanisms. These eventually will lead to severe lung damage over time.73 It is a
fact that the nanoparticles are much smaller in size than cellular organelles and easily
penetrate through the cells of biological systems, damaging them by affecting their typical

function. One of the undesirable consequences is problems like tissue inflammation caused in humans.74 These days, different methods of modification of water treatment membranes using
nano-additives have been reported, by which the safe/minimal release of nanoparticles can be
assured. The modification of polysulfone (PSf) membranes with bio-inspired polydopamine
(PD) coating and Ag NPs immobilization for the mitigation of biofouling have been reported by Tang et al.75 The modified membranes have been reported to show high Ag NPs stability
in the membrane matrix with minimal silver release as the in-situ immobilization of silver is achieved through the reduction of Ag+ ions by the catechol groups of PD. Another important reason is that the O and N- sites present in PD act as anchors for silver nanoparticles via metal coordination through charge transfer.76 The attachment of nanoparticles by covalent bonding
with the base membrane using bridging agents such as cysteamine has also been reported as an effective way to mitigate nanoparticle leaching from the membrane surface.77 Son et al.
reported that the nanoparticle leach out can be addressed by immobilizing nanomaterials through UV irradiation.78 When polymer nanofibers with small quantities of AgNO3 are UV irradiated, a predominant generation of Ag NPs has been noted which offers strong microbial
activity with high stability. Some researchers reported that the incorporation of nanomaterials through physical blending can very much reduce the nanoparticle leaching.79,80 Nevertheless,
whatever may be the modification techniques employed, a continuous monitoring of
nanoparticle concentration in the permeate water during membrane filtration experiments
using techniques such as atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) as well as inductively
coupled plasma - mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) are recommended in order to avoid
undesirable effects to the environment.

sections.heading: 3.1 Single-walled and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs & MWCNTs)
sections.text:
Carbon based nanomaterials such as carbon nanodots, and carbon nanoparticles have
been employed in solar cells,81 energy storage/conversion devices,82-84 microwave absorption,85 and heavy metal adsorption/removal from wastewater.86-88 Due to their excellent
environmental stability and large specific surface area. Among the several carbon based
nanomaterials, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) (both single walled and multi-walled) are widely employed as nano-additives in water treatment membranes.89,90 These incredible structures
possess excellent electronic and mechanical strength, which is at least 100 times stronger and
six times lighten than steel, and these structures impart good strength to almost any material
into which it is incorporated. A schematic structural representation of both single walled and
multi walled CNTs are given as Figure 3. Due to incredible chemical inertness, high
mechanical stability, and high specific surface area with excellent water transport properties,
CNTs have received tremendous attention in the development and fabrication of novel composite membranes for water treatment applications.91-93 In particular, the orientation of
CNTs in the membrane matrices has been reported to play a most significant role in membrane water permeation and the mechanism of fast mass transport properties.94 Gethard
et al. investigated the effect of vertical CNT immobilization in the pores of hydrophobic
membranes and reported that the water desalination properties improved due to altered water – membrane interactions.95 The water permeation rate through the vertically aligned CNT
(VA-CNT) nanocomposite membranes has been enhanced 3-4 fold when compared to the
unmodified membrane due to three possible water transportation pathways: (i) direct water
transport through the membrane, (ii) nano-confinement boosted water flux and (iii) rapid mass transport through CNT pores.94 Likewise, these enhanced water transportation
properties have also been attributed to the ballistic motion of water inside CNTs because of

different water penetration pathways through CNT modified membranes is shown in Figure
4. Gusev et al. suggested that the incorporation of CNTs into compact/less porous membranes
can increase the water permeation properties due to ultrafast mass transport from the end of one CNT to another.97 But, to become a bottle neck, high quality CNTs with no impurity and
extra complicated end – opening techniques are required to align CNTs in membrane matrices in a vertical direction.98 However, these complications have been addressed by
adopting the chemical vapor deposition method (CVD) to grow vertically aligned CNTs
before preparing the composite membranes by using the dope casting phase inversion method.99 Li et al. compared the performance of randomly aligned CNT membranes with that
of vertically aligned ones (R-CNT) and reported the VR-CNT membranes exhibited 3 times faster water transportation and better foulant retention properties than R-CNT membranes.94
Further, several researchers reported that CNTs have shown great promise in enhancing the material properties of polymers.100,101 The high aspect ratio, coupled with relatively low
density as well as high strength and stiffness, has made CNTs to be effective nano-filler in
polymeric materials. Also, like silver nanoparticles, CNTs can exhibit antibacterial activity,
and this is why CNTs are considered to be a good alternative for fabrication of membranes with improved hydrophilicity and antifouling properties.102-104 But, CNT nanocomposite
membranes are disadvantaged by the solubilization problem encountered during the
preparation and fabrication of CNT blend membranes. This results since these membranes are
insoluble in water or in other organic solvents. However, Lin et al. suggested that
functionalization of CNTs with polymer groups can be of help, since when functionalized,
the CNTs and the polymer matrix become structurally similar so that the dispersion of CNTs in polymers can be achievable.104 Generally, it has been reported by several researchers that,

There are different types of CNTs, which are categorized into single-walled
(SWCNTs) and multi-walled nanotubes (MWCNTs) which have been widely used in the form of raw/functionalized material.107 A single-walled CNT has a type of regular straw
structure, with a cylindrical shape, consisting of only one layer/shell of graphene. This has
been widely investigated in water treatment membranes, for the removal of natural organic
matter (NOM), which is considered to be one of the most problematic issues in water
treatment.
Heo et al. addressed the effect of the addition of SWCNTs on the filtration and
rejection of humic acid (HA) under different hydrodynamic conditions.108 The studies reveal
that, the addition of SWCNTs to the UF process did not significantly exacerbate the permeate

surface creates a more porous surface which easily permits the water to pass through without
any additional fouling resistance. However, the SWCNT-UF membranes showed increased
rejection trends as the SWCNT binding site adsorbs HA during fouling experiments. Also, it
should be noted that, the resistance and the fouling layer on the membrane greatly depends
upon HA adsorption and deposition, as the size of SWCNTs were too large to block the surface pores.108
The performance evaluation of MWCNT incorporated aromatic polyamide
nanocomposite membranes was reported by Shawky et al.109 In their study, various
concentrations of polyamide membranes were fabricated and the MWCNTs were loaded at
different wt.% in 10 wt.% polyamide membrane. The increasing loading of MWCNTs from 0
to 10 wt.%, results in more hydrophobic membrane with a lower permeability as well as a
higher NaCl and humic acid rejection. This is attributed to the formation of the network
structure in the membrane.
The modification of poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC) UF membranes by SWCNTs was
attempted by Zhao et al.110 Compared to neat PVC, the resultant nanocomposite membrane
exhibited enhanced hydrophilic performance with improved permeate flux. However, the
added SWCNTs caused some undesirable effects in the surface roughness and antimicrobial
properties. In other words, the nanoparticle loaded membranes showed high surface
roughness and no antibacterial properties when the membrane samples were tested using a
halo zone and colony counting study. The former can lead to easy membrane fouling while the latter makes the membranes susceptible to biofouling.111 This is due to the fact that the
polymer wrapping surrounds the added SWCNTs in the nanocomposite membranes, thereby

reducing the contact chances between the SWCNTs and bacteria. This might also be due to
the bio-effect changes that occurred in the nanoparticle while blending with polymer. Also,
the tiny quantity of added SWCNTs might not be sufficient to impart antibacterial properties to the base membrane.112
Research on the development of functionalized CNTs (F-CNTs) is also a trend these
days, since the F-CNTs perform even better than the unmodified materials. A number of
different modes of functionalization of CNTs have been invented by the researchers such as tip functionalization, core functionalization,93 etc., and its schematic representation has been
produced as Figure 5. Even though the F-CNTs have widely been explored in various fields due to their great potential,113, 114 these are highly utilized in the field of macromolecular
separation since the transport of water molecules in F-CNTs is analogous to the transport of water through polymeric membrane pores.115, 116 In that order, the acidified CNTs were
generally prepared by treating them with H2SO4/HNO3 acid mixture under high temperature with constant stirring. It has been reported that, when oxidized multi-walled carbon
nanotubes (O-MWCNTs) were added to the membrane, the viscosity of the casting solution increased, eventually leading to void formation due to delayed de-mixing.117

In addition to this, the pore-like structure on the neat membrane surface also has
disappeared by O-MWCNTs incorporation.117, 118 However, generally the nanoparticles
addition will enhance the solvent-non solvent exchange during phase mixing that may lead to
instantaneous de-mixing as well, in this case with O-MWCNTs, it seems that the effect of
viscosity dominates the effect of solvent non-solvent exchange rate and that’s why macrovoid
formations in the membrane occur. Besides this, the addition of O-CNTs can also have a
considerable effect on membrane hydrophilicity and morphological properties. The O-CNTs
incorporated membranes show improved permeation and pure water flux (PWF) when
compared to the concern pristine membranes, as the finger-like macrovoids have elongated across the nanocomposite membrane matrix.107, 117 Also it was reported by Wu et al. that the
surface of the O-MWCNTs modified membranes has a much thicker surface than the
unmodified membranes, with a decreasing membrane contact angle. This is due to the porous structure of O-MWCNTs that plays a more dominant role influencing PWF.119

Besides acidified CNTs, several water treatment studies that addressed the utilization
of other F-CNTs (carboxyl, hydroxyl, oxidized, doped, amidized, azidized, etc.) in the
fabrication of water filtration nanocomposite membrane indicated that, in addition to
unmodified CNTs, these materials can also act as a good membrane performance modifier.
These materials can also bring about considerable changes to the polymeric membrane morphology, fouling and permeation properties.120-122 Gupta et al. fabricated polysulfone
(PSf) blended SWCNT (PSf-SWCNT) and PSf-oxidized/amide/azide SWCNT
nanocomposite membranes and studied their permeate flux, porosity, pore size and their ability in the removal of metal ions such as Cr (VI), As (III) and Pb (II).120 They observed
that the pore size of PS membranes keep on decreasing with the addition of functionalized
SWCNTs, which leads to the effective removal of metal ions from drinking water. This is due
to the spontaneous migration of hydrophilic SWCNTs to the membrane interface to reduce
the interfacial energy. Many studies have revealed that hydrophilicity and surface
morphology are the characteristic parameters, which have a strong influence on the membrane transport properties.121 The performance of carboxyl functionalized MWCNTs
incorporated brominated poly (2,6-dimethyl-1,4-phenylene oxide) (BPPO) membrane was investigated by Wu et al.119 The resultant nanocomposite membrane exhibited high
hydrophilicity and excellent separation properties with high chemical resistivity. In addition
to MWCNTs, triethanolamine (TEOA) was also used as a cross-linking agent since it
increases the hydrophilicity and anti-fouling properties of the resulting membrane due to its
three hydroxyl groups. The zwitterions containing the quaternary ammonium group of TEOA
reacts with the BPPO and carboxyl groups of MWCNTs, thereby imparting hydrophilicity to
the nanocomposite membrane matrix. Generally, there are two main factors considered to be
responsible for greater permeation through F-CNTs incorporated UF membranes; and these are hydrophilicity and membrane pore structure.115,119 Firstly, the improved hydrophilicity

caused by added F-CNTs subsequently causes an increase in membrane water flux. Further,
the increased exchange rate between the solvent and non-solvent during phase inversion
promotes an increase in membrane pore size. A similar supporting study for the above
mentioned statement has also been reported by Lawrence Arockiasamy et al., which reports
on the performance evaluation of carboxyl functionalized MWCNTs incorporated PPSU membranes.122 During the study of compaction, the nanocomposite membranes showed a
slight flux decline after which steady state is achieved after 2-3 h. The membrane attained a
uniform pore size during the compaction process and came to steady state, these showing the
significant influence of membrane pore size on water flux. Furthermore, the very significant
enhancement of water flux in carboxyl-MWCNTs incorporated nanocomposite membranes is reported due to the enhanced segmental gap between the base polymer and added F-CNTs.123
It was also reported that the addition of carboxyl-MWCNTs can enhance the miscibility of
resultant polymeric membrane due to the poor adhesion properties between the membrane
and CNTs, further leading to an increase in the membrane void volume that results in larger sized pore formation.124 Besides this, the percentage water uptake and hydrophilicity were
enhanced by the –COOH moieties of the added F-CNTs present in the nanocomposite
membranes.
While considering the foulant rejection performance by the effect of O-CNTs on the
rejection properties of the concern nanocomposite membranes, these are conflicting reports that have shown that CNTs have no/negligible influence on the rejection properties.125 Some
other researchers had evidently reported that CNTs considerably altered the membrane pore structure.126 Wu et al. reported that, the MWCNTs incorporated BPPO membranes show a
high level of egg albumin rejections, since there is an electrostatic repulsion between the foulant and membrane surface.119 Generally, the proteins or foulants absorb on the membrane

surface through hydrophobic–hydrophobic interactions which result in the foulant cake layer
formation. The carboxylated MWCNTs have a tendency to reduce membrane fouling through
the increased hydrophilicity and negatively charged groups on the outer surface of the base membrane.127 The nanocomposite membranes also exhibited a lower flux decline than the pristine membranes due to the higher hydrophilic groups established by the added CNTs.128
The F-CNTs nanocomposite membranes also had a high removal rate for polyethylene glycol
(PEG) macromolecules due to the interaction between hydroxyl groups and the hydrophilic
surface of the PEG and membrane respectively, which was attributed to the pyrrolidone groups of the hydrophilic agent.129 It was reported by Liu et al. that the bovine serum albumin
(BSA) rejection of F-CNTs nanocomposite membranes increases with increasing the pH
values, and this result is brought about by the repulsive force between the BSA and COOgroups of the membranes, which becomes stronger at a higher pH.130 It was continuously
reported in the literature that there are mainly two factors which are inter-related which play
the most important role in the solute rejection performance of CNTs incorporated nanocomposite membranes,131 namely (i) increment in hydrophilicity, and (ii) augmentation
in water flux. The increment in hydrophilicity affects the rejection properties of the
membrane in a positive way that enhances the total amount of water molecules permeating
through the membrane without enhancing the permeability of the foulants. Further, the higher
water permeation can also affect the retention values negatively, due to gagging of the solute.132 Several researchers also reported that the low rejection performance might be as a result of slightly larger pores or more interconnected pores with increased hydrophilicity.133
While considering salt rejection, the MWCNTs incorporated nanocomposite membranes have a more compact structure than the pristine membranes.134 This might be due to the strong
interaction between the base polymer matrix and the added MWCNTs, suggesting a network structure in nanocomposite membranes.135 Further, it was strongly reported that the network

sections.heading: 3.2 Graphene oxide nanomaterials
sections.text:
In recent decades, graphene oxide (GO) has emerged as an outstanding hydrophilic
modifier for water treatment membranes. Due to the presence of a large number of oxygen-
containing functional groups such as hydroxyl, carboxyl and epoxy groups, GO possesses good thermal and mechanical stability, resistance towards chemical and microbial fouling,138, 139 high surface area and innocuity, which makes it as an additive in water treatment membranes.140-142 Researchers have adopted numerous methods such as coating, in-situ immobilization, blending, etc., to incorporate GO into the membrane matrix.143 A significant

24
number of research articles demonstrated that a membrane incorporated with GO showed enhanced hydrophilic performance and improved water flux.144, 145 Lee et al. reported that the
GO membrane has a higher water permeability and anti-biofouling capability due to its hydrophilicity and electrostatic repulsion characteristics.146
Jin et al. prepared GO incorporated nanocomposite membranes and studied the role of
added GO in modifying the membrane structure during phase inversion.147 They reported that
the overall porosity and mean pore size of the resultant membrane had increased, and as a
consequence, the permeation properties had been significantly enhanced. Zhao et al.
demonstrated the effect of the addition of GO in to a PVDF membrane matrix via blending
and investigated the enhanced performance in terms of hydrophilicity and anti-fouling properties.148 They suggested that the large amount of –OH groups in the GO nanosheets
accelerate the water-solvent exchange rate during phase inversion, thereby improving the
hydrophilicity and membrane surface pore size. In the meantime, the hydraulic resistance of
the GO nanocomposite membrane decreased due to the development of finger-like structures
in the bulk. The effect of incorporation of GO on the separation and permeation performance of PVDF membranes was investigated by Xia et al.149 An obvious increase in PWF was
reported in this work due to the addition of GO. This enhancement was attributed to the
oxygen-containing functional groups present in GO, which had undergone a spontaneous
migration to the membrane surface during the phase inversion process. It has been well
proven that the presence of these oxygen-containing groups have a positive influence on
membrane permeation characteristics by attracting the water molecules inside the membrane matrix resulting in a much faster water passage through the concern membrane.150-152 Hu et
al. demonstrated that when GO thin sheets are added to a base polymer, it could effectively improve the physical properties of the resultant nanocomposite membrane.153 Besides

permeability, when added at small concentrations, GO has a significant effect in altering membrane surface morphologies.154 The added GO changes the larger peaks and valleys
present in the surface of the membrane to smaller peaks. These results were observed due to
the low electrostatic interaction and good compatibility between the membrane matrix and
added nano-GO. As a consequence, GO incorporated nanocomposite membranes exhibit a much smoother and less rough surface than the respective neat membrane.155 These kinds of observation have been reported by many other researchers.156,157 In the case of anti-fouling
performance of the GO nanocomposite membrane, the adsorption of foulants by the
membrane surface seems to be much less in GO added membranes when compared to the
respective neat membranes. This gets even more reduced when increasing the GO
concentration. This is due to the formation of a water layer on the nanocomposite membrane
surface and it was reported by several researchers that this phenomenon is responsible for the reduction in foulant adsorption.141,153 Shao et al. investigated the rejection and fouling
behavior of GO incorporated nanocomposite membranes and reported that the negatively charged membranes were responsible for a gradual decline in the adsorbed amount of HA.158
Generally, the incorporation of GO results on the membrane surface becoming
negatively charged. This concept was explained by Kumar et al. in such a way that since the
nanocomposite membranes and humic acid (HA) both are negatively charged, these repel each other due to electrostatic repulsion.156 Hence, the adsorbed amount of HA was greatly
reduced and that’s why these membranes exhibited a higher hydrophilicity and improved
antifouling properties. As a result of improved fouling resistance, the flux recovery ratio
(FRR) values of the nanocomposite membranes also were enhanced and this clearly denotes
that the adsorbed HA can be easily washed off by simple water washing or by using a dilute
solution of NaOH. The most important advantage of GO assisted membranes is that they

seem to be highly resistant to chlorine and can be employed widely in reverse osmosis (RO) membrane systems.159, 160 Besides this, GO incorporated nanocomposite membranes involve a simple and cost-effective fabrication process.161 Choi et al. studied the performance of GO
nanosheets incorporated polyamide membranes for RO applications and demonstrated that
there is a dual functional protective layer formation on the resultant nanocomposite
membrane and it was reported to be responsible for its improved antifouling properties without compromising chlorine separation performance.162 Also, the permeation and rejection
properties have been considerably enhanced due to the higher hydrophilicity brought about
by the added GO. It has been demonstrated, with the support of different characterizations,
that the incorporation of GO favors the formation of a hydrophilic cross-linking network. As
a consequence, the hydrophilicity, pore size, porosity and roughness of the nanocomposite membrane can be effectively improved.8 Other than hydrophilicity and foulant separation
applications, GO incorporated membranes were also investigated in terms of anti-biofouling
activity and some interesting results have been reported. The toxicity of GO nanomaterials
towards microorganisms is highly controversial to date since publications in the literature simultaneously report both toxic and non-toxic effects of GO.163,164 Generally, like any other
nanomaterials, the toxicity of GO depends to a great extent upon the chemical structure, size,
number of layers, mode of incorporation to the substrate, concentration of GO used, contact time, etc.165 The particle size of GO has a great influence on the dispersity and antibacterial
activity since sharp edges and corners of GO play an important role in determining the physicochemical interactions of GO with microorganisms.166 Further, the GO nanoparticles
with relatively sharper nanowalls and edges exhibited better antimicrobial property as these sharp edges render the survival of microorganisms in their vicinity difficult.167 So far, several
mechanisms such as nanoknives, wrapping, and oxidative stress have been proposed for understanding the antibacterial characteristics of GO nanomaterials.168,169 Bhatti et al.

investigated the antibacterial performance of GO incorporated PES membrane and reported
that there is a significant reduction of 70.8% in the growth of S. typhi cells compared to pristine PES membranes.170 The excellent antibacterial activity of GO incorporated
membranes is often attributed to the oxidative nature of GO which causes disruption between
in cell membrane leading to bacterial cell death and the loss of cell viability in the vicinity of the nanocomposite membranes.171 However, at relatively high additive concentrations, the
nanoparticle agglomerate formation limits the antibacterial potential of GO by decreasing contact with other biomolecules like proteins and DNA.166 Also, when dealing with proteins
like BSA, due to non-covalent adsorption, the antimicrobial activity of GO incorporated membranes decreases.172 Hence, it becomes necessary to modify the GO surface to bring
about better dispersion ability in polymer membrane matrices.
Besides using unmodified GO, various researchers also investigated the performance of grafted, functionalized/modified GO.173 Their investigation results revealed that the
membranes possess high foulant removal efficiency. This is due to the fact that the low
porosity and high surface charge concentration acts as a strong hindrance for the passage of the negatively charged foulant molecules.174-177 GO contains a multiple number of oxygen
functionalities which imparts good mechanical stability and water permeation to the resultant nanocomposite membrane.178 However, the compatibility and dispersion of any
inorganic/organic component in the polymer matrix is always a challenge in achieving excellent membrane performance.179 For instance, the most significant disadvantage of GO
while employed as a membrane modifier is that it easily stacks together with the formation of non-selective voids in the membrane and leads to selectivity impairment.180, 181 It was reported by Zhu et al.182 and Schiffman et al.183 that grafting polymers can effectively
enhance the compatibility and dispersion of inorganic fillers in the organic base matrix. Yu et

al. fabricated hyper-branched polyethylenimine (HPEI) functionalized GO incorporated PES
nanocomposite membranes and reported that the HPEI-GO/PES membranes have excellent anti-fouling properties, good mechanical strength and Young’s modulus.184 However
unexpectedly, the water permeation properties of the membrane decreased with the addition
of HPEI-GO. The undesirable effect in water permeation denotes that only increasing the
compatibility between polymer and nanoparticle is not sufficient to achieve a good
performing membrane. In order to overcome this problem, Yang et al. synthesized the
functionalized GO using branched polyethylenimine (PEI) and incorporated it into a
brominated poly (2,6-dimethyl-1,4-phenylene oxide) (BPPO) matrix by covalent bond interaction to form a cross-linking network.185 The resultant membrane exhibited six times
higher permeation than the neat BPPO membrane and 2.5 times higher permeation than the
GO-BPPO membrane with high foulant rejection because the cross-linking network
formation between PEI-GO and the BPPO matrices provide passages for fast water
permeation. Nair et al. demonstrated that the oxidized regions of added GO causes strong
interaction with intercalating water, thereby enhancing the water permeation properties of the concern membrane.186 Further, the incorporation of high hydrophilic PEI-GO into the base
membrane matrix caused a rougher and a higher membrane porosity. Commonly, a rough
membrane surface leads to an efficient filtration area that directly increases the membrane permeation properties.187, 188 And it was widely reported that the coagulation value of the GOpolymer casting solution has a great influence on thermodynamic stability.189 That is, the lower the coagulation, the faster will be the phase inversion,190 and hence, the resultant
nanocomposite membrane exhibits a more porous structure and this phenomenon is also supported by the rejection performance of the concern membrane.191

With the ultra-thin 2D structure and multi-functional surface chemistry GO finds
potential applications in the separation field. However, it is difficult to use GO in nano-
filtration (NF) membranes. This is because the non-adjustable pore channels within the GO sheets limit the fabrication of versatile NF membranes.192, 193 Also, it was widely reported
that the pore channels formed in the GO nanocomposite membranes seemed to be too narrow
to perform as an effective NF membrane. As a consequence, the mass transfer resistivity of the concern membrane increases and permeation performances decreases.194 In order to
overcome this obstacle and to enhance the performance of GO in NF membranes, a new
strategy that involves the coupling of inorganic/organic materials with GO has been widely investigated by researchers.195,196 The fabrication of magnesium silicate modified reduced
GO deposited polyacrylonitrile (PAN) UF membranes for organic molecule separation was investigated by Liang et al.196 Further, it was reported by Goh et al. that the increasing
concentration of foulant solution lowers the removal efficiency of the nanocomposite
membrane. This phenomenon was attributed to the insufficient negatively charged groups that are present in the nanocomposite membrane matrix.197 From this it has been proven that
GO incorporated membranes can effectively remove the foulants at low concentrations. Also,
the surface hydrophilicity enhancement in the PSF membrane due to small amounts of GO nanosheets embedding TiO2 has been demonstrated by Kumar et al.198 This is because the interfacial gap between the added GO-TiO2 creates additional water channels in the PSF membrane matrix, and makes water permeation through the modified membranes easy.
Further, the water holding capacity of the membranes was greatly enhanced due to the increase in membrane pore size and porosity.199 Some research work also demonstrates the
agglomeration issue, which is considered to be one of the more predominant drawbacks in
nanocomposite membranes. This can be solved/prevented with the help of GO embedding via
the sol-gel method, since the GO nanosheets anchor the hydrophilic functional groups in

concern metal oxide nanoparticle.200, 201 The concept was that the incorporation of GO-TiO2 makes the barrier layer of the nanocomposites more hydrophilic and negatively charged due
to the presence of the carboxylic acid and Ti-OH groups in the membrane matrix. Likewise,
the synthesis and characterization of GO-SiO2 incorporated nanocomposite PVDF membrane was reported by Xu et al.175 The investigation relating to the GO blended with one-
dimensional oxidized CNTs (GO-OMWCNTs) on the permeation and antifouling properties of the PVDF nanocomposite membranes has been studied by Zhang et al.202 These
researchers reported that the nanocomposite membranes prepared with the incorporation of
GO-OMWCNTs showed superior permeation and antifouling properties due to the formation
of a hydration layer on the membrane caused by high hydrophilicity. For better
understanding, a graphical representation of this above phenomenon has been provided as
Figure 6.202
Figure 6. Schematic illustration of anti-fouling mechanisms of pristine and modified membranes [J. Membr. Sci. 2013, 448, 81–92, DOI:10.1016/j.memsci.2013.07.064].

due to the strong van der Waals forces and inter-planer stacking. This drawback limits the
performance of nanocomposite membranes. In order to overcome this, the formation of a co-

sections.heading: 4. Metal oxide nanoparticles
sections.text:
Synthesis and incorporation of metal oxide nanoparticles (NPs) on to the membrane
matrix in order to enhance the permeation and antifouling properties of the base membranes have been reported by numerous researchers.203, 204 This is occurs because the metal oxide
nanoparticle incorporated membranes show improved mechanical as well as chemical
resistance combined with enhanced permeation properties without compromising the foulant

rejection efficiency.205, 206 Since the added metal oxide NPs provide a superior permeation
pathway for selective permeation, these membranes show excellent separation properties as well.207 This is because the additions of metal oxide NPs have a significant effect on the
membrane formation mechanisms which leads to an effective alteration in resultant membrane morphology and surface modifications.208 Irrespective of the metal oxide NPs
used, it was globally reported that there is a contrast difference in the morphology of the
membrane sub layer before and after the incorporation of metal oxide nano-fillers. This takes
place during phase inversion or other kinds of membrane formation processes, due to the
phenomenon of grain disturbances caused by the added metal oxide NPs. This leads to the
formation of a much more porous top layer and increased pore distribution at the membrane top interface.209, 210 Generally, these metal oxide NPs have been employed to modify the
permeation and antifouling properties of the base membrane in two methods; One is simple
physical blending of polymer, solvent and the selected metal oxide NPs, and another is
coating/deposition of metal oxide NPs on to the surface of the base membrane. While the physical blending method is advantaged by its simple membrane preparation part.211 the
surface deposition method is advantaged by the enhanced separation and stability properties
of the resultant membrane. In this way, the surface modification has been done without
altering the actual base membrane structure and morphology and by that way, the foulant rejection properties can also be enhanced.212 In the case of water treatment membrane
applications metal oxide nanoparticles such as TiO2, SiO2, CuO, MnO2, MgO, CeO2, etc., are showing great potential due to their simple synthesis and their promising applications.213

sections.heading: 4.1 Titanium dioxide nanoparticles
sections.text:

in the fabrication of nanocomposite UF membranes due to its high level of stability, low cost

and photocatalytic activity.214-216 It was reported by Padaki et al. that the addition of nano-
TiO2 to polysulfone (PSf) can effectively increase the permeation, mechanical and thermal resistance properties of the resultant membrane due to the surface hydrophilicity enhancement caused by nano TiO2.217 The effect of incorporation of different sized TiO2 particles (25, 105, and 500 nm) at different concentrations on the permeation and antifouling properties of PES membrane was investigated by Vatanpour et al.117 When compared to 105
and 500 nm, the membranes incorporated with 25 nm sized TiO2 particles exhibited better hydrophilicity and antifouling properties due to their improved dispersity. In spite of the large
surface area of the 500 nm sized TiO2 when compared to the 25 nm, their agglomeration at high concentrations reduces their effective surface area. The difference in nano-TiO2 behavior was attributed to the rutile phase present in 25 nm TiO2 nanoparticles. Hamid et al. developed PSf membranes with different concentrations of nano-TiO2 and studied the improvement in the morphological and separation performances of the resultant nanocomposite membranes using humic acid (HA) as a foulant.218 Compared to pristine PSf,
all the PSf-TiO2 membranes exhibited a relatively smoother surface with lesser nodules confirming that the added TiO2 not only alters the membrane hydrophilicity properties but also has a significant effect on membrane surface roughness parameters. Besides this, the
high separation of HA was attributed to the significant difference between membrane pore size and the size of HA.219 The effect of increasing concentrations of nanoporous Titania in the morphological characteristics of PES was studied by Low et al.220 In this study, all the
Titania incorporated nanocomposite membranes developed a finger like top layer followed by
a spongy sublayer and then, a macrovoidic bottom layer. And when the concentration of
Titania increased the macrovoid formation in the bulk also increased due to the enhanced
dope viscosity caused by the nanoporous Titania.

Figure 7. Microvoid formation in PES membrane caused by nanoporous Titania [Ind. Eng. Chem. Res. 2015, 54, 11188–11198, DOI: 10.1021/acs.iecr.5b03147].
In recent years, many researchers have studied the surface deposition of nano-
TiO2into membrane surfaces because of its high photocatalytic and hydrophilic effect in enhancing the antifouling properties of the concern membrane since the nano-TiO2 has a tendency to decay the organic foulants and microbes that are present in the feed water.220-222 It
was widely reported that the incorporation of TiO2 nanoparticles has a tendency to increase the number of spherulites of the concern membrane and decreases their pore size.220 It was
found by Peng et al. that the mobility of polymer chain segments in the interfacial region can
be suppressed by the addition of nano-TiO2 and that this phenomenon depends on the concentration of nanoparticles.223 The self-assembly of TiO2 nanoparticles on PES UF membrane via a synergetic analysis method for enhancing the antifouling behavior was done by Li et al.224 A tremendously enhanced antifouling effect was observed in the composite

was attributed to the hydrophilic nature of the self-assembled membrane. It was reported by
the authors that the self-assembled TiO2 NPs around the membrane pores enhances the hydrophilicity of concern composite membrane and forms a hydrophilic layer in the vicinity
of the membrane surface. This layer prevents the direct contact of foulants to the membrane surface and thereby, improves the antifouling properties.225, 226 Luo et al. investigated the
performance of TiO2 blended with sulfonated PES (SPES/TiO2) nanocomposite membranes and reported that there is a remarkable change in the membrane hydrophilicity due to rich hydroxyl content in the nano-TiO2 surface.227 Also, a significant increase in the rejection properties of the nanocomposite membrane is observed by the author. This phenomenon is
attributed to the self-assembly between the added nano-TiO2 and SPES with ether bond, sulfonic group and sulfuryl group. Many studies have demonstrated that the dispersity and
photocatalytic behavior of TiO2 in solvents can be improved by coating TiO2 nanoparticles with a relatively low surface energy material so that the particle agglomeration at high concentrations can be avoided.228 Besides this, the incorporation of nano-TiO2 also plays a significant role in reducing the fouling properties of the concern membranes and ensures prolonged performance in industrial plants.229 Recently, the issue of high surface tension
between the TiO2 NPs and PVDF polymer has been fixed by the partial hydroxylation of PVDF polymer via the Fenton reaction, which is followed by the incorporation of TiO2 NPs via the phase inversion method.228 The resultant PVDF-OH/TiO2 membrane exhibited better dispersion, and reduced particle agglomeration with a high reactive surface area due to strong interactions between the TiO2 NPs and the polymer.229

size decreases. Hence, it becomes even more beneficial when nanoparticles are functionalized

trimethylolpropanetriacrylate (TMPTA) to impart high hydrophilicity and good optical properties to the nanoparticles.230 In their work, the super hydrophilicity of the TMPTA-TiO2 was evidenced by water contact angle measurements which were less than 5º. The synthesis

functionalized TiO2, the resultant nanocomposite membranes a exhibited high permeate flux and improved antifouling properties. Further, the authors have done silver decoration on the
surface of the hybrid membranes and those membranes were shown to possess antimicrobial
properties due to the toxicity of decorated silver. Madaeni et al. compared two different methods of immobilization of TiO2 NPs on the PVDF membrane surface.232 One method is self-assembly of TiO2 NPs on the surface of poly(acrylic acid) (PAA) and another one is the in situ immobilization of acrylic acid monomer functionalized–TiO2 by the ‘grafting from’ technique. These researchers investigated these antifouling properties using whey solution.232
The authors reported that, the ‘grafting from’ method is better than the ‘self-assembling’
method in terms of nanoparticle durability in surface modified membranes. Because of the
low stability of in situ immobilization, the nanoparticles get detached from the membrane
matrix during washing, and therefore, the antifouling properties of the membranes were
reduced. But in the case of the ‘grafting from’ method, the strong/high interaction between
the PAA functionalized TiO2 and PVDF surfaces increases the stability of the nanoparticles on the membrane matrix.233 When considering flux recovery compared to bare membranes,
the PAA-TiO2 grafted membranes were reported to exhibit better performance due to the existence of a –COOH group in PAA.234 During immobilization, the nano-TiO2 were randomly attached to the functional groups of PAA on the pores of the concern membrane,
which mostly gets detached during washing leading to a reduction in antifouling properties.235 Other than mere nanoparticle functionalization, some researchers were also
experimenting with making use of co-ordination chemistry based approaches, in which the
advantages of amphiphilic copolymers and inorganic nanoparticles were combined together to fabricate a membrane surface with high fouling resistance.157, 236 For incidence, Zhao et al.

in their work have constructed a optimally integrated fouling resistant membrane using
poly(hexafluorobutyl acrylate) (PHFBA) and TiO2 as a copolymer and inorganic nanoparticles, respectively.157 The formation of metal–organic coordination interactions
between the PHFBA and TiO2 during membrane formation imparts a multi-defense mechanism and significant morphological changes established by customizing the PHFBA
and TiO2 mass ratio. The graphical representation of morphological and roughness characteristics of PHFBA-TiO2 modified membrane have been shown in Figure 9 to render a better understanding regarding the modified membrane formation mechanism. In addition to
these above mentioned properties, TiO2 nanoparticles incorporated membranes have also been extensively investigated for water disinfection/antibacterial activity due to efficiency in generating high oxidizing hydroxyl radicals under UV irradiation.237 That is, when subjected
to any kind of irradiation such as UV, visible light, etc., the generation of energy happens due to the excitation of electron in the photo-catalyst.238 This leads to the creation of a couple of
positively charged electron holes and negatively charged free electrons which react with the
atmospheric oxygen and water, forming reactive oxygen species (OH radicals, hydrogen peroxide etc.,).239 These hydroxyl radicals effectively react with biomolecules such as
bacteria, thereby exhibiting antibiofouling activity in their respective nanocomposite membranes.240 The effectiveness of nitrogen doped–TiO2 nanoparticle incorporated membranes under visible light irradiation has been reported by Amin et al.241 During doping,
the diffusion of nitrogen atoms into TiO2 takes place, and when irradiated, these N-TiO2 nanoparticles have effectively destroyed the cyanobacterial toxin present in the waste water
as a result of their high reactivity. Further, another important advantage of TiO2, in terms of biocidal activity is that of prolonged life time.242 This is because of the unaltered nature of
TiO2 during the photo-degradation process involving microorganisms and organic pollutants.

sections.heading: 4.2. Zinc oxide nanoparticles
sections.text:
Like TiO2, zinc oxide (ZnO) NPs show a significant effect in enhancing the anti-
biofouling and antifungal properties of polymeric water treatment membranes.243,244 In addition to this, these NPs possess UV filtering features as well.245 Besides nano-size,
researchers even employ the micro sized ZnO in order to enhance the hydrophilicity properties of the concern membrane for pervaporation.246 The influence of ZnO NPs in
enhancing the filtration and antifouling properties of PES membrane was studied by Balta et al.247 The results from permeation and fouling experiments suggested that the desired
properties have been greatly enhanced in the nanocomposite membranes because of the high

the addition of ZnO NPs can cause significant enhancement in the value of the 𝑇𝑔 nanocomposite membranes due to the interaction between the base polymer and hydroxyl groups present on the surface of the ZnO NPs.248 The excellent thermal stability exhibited by
the nanocomposite membranes can also be attributed to the dispersity of the ZnO NPs in the solvent, which provides a relatively larger surface area for the polymer–NPs interactions.249
Maximous et al. reported that the thermal stability and hydrophilicity properties of the nanocomposite membranes increases with increasing ZnO concentration.250 The
hydrophilicity effect, caused by the addition of nano-ZnO, increases the solvent non-solvent
exchange rate during phase inversion as a consequence of which the water permeation
properties of the resultant membrane were enhanced. The enhancement in the hydrophilicity factor also promotes membrane porosity.251 In addition to this, it was reported that the
decomposition temperature of nano-ZnO (1975ºC) is higher than that of nano-TiO2 (1855ºC) due to the higher active surface area. That is because the nano-ZnO easily becomes hydrophilic by the quick absorption of hydrophilic -OH groups.252 It was widely reported that
nano-ZnO has a great influence in improving the water permeation properties of the concern base membranes by improving their hydrophilicity.253 It was reported by Liang et al. that the
irreversible fouling occurring in PES membrane was greatly reduced by the supplementation of nano-ZnO due to its enhanced hydrophilicity effects.254 Also, due to its low cost, ZnO
nanoparticles are considered to be one of the most popular nanomaterials, and many researchers have been using this as a new alternative for nano-TiO2.255 Due to good photo catalytic properties, nano-ZnO has been widely employed for membrane self-cleaning by photo catalysis.256 Some researchers recently have studied the combined performance of ZnO
nanoparticles and graphene oxide and reported effect of incorporation of these materials as a nano-hydrophilic modifier into the base polymer matrix.257,258 This is because even though

membrane, beyond a certain concentration the ZnO particles form agglomerates in the
polymer dope due to their nano-size which affects their uniform distribution during membrane formation.259 Among several metal oxide nanoparticles, ZnO NPs exhibit higher levels of toxicity compared to CuO NPs.260 Worldwide researchers have been employing ZnO
NPs in order to protect the membranes from gram negative and gram positive bacteria such as E. coli, B. subtilis, etc.261 This is because the ZnO NPs have a tendency to change the
microenvironments close to the bacteria/other micro-organisms, and to increase the solubility. This can eventually cause damage in bacterial cells.262 The mechanism of bacterial cells damage caused by the incorporation of Zn/Ag NPs is shown in Figure 10.263

functionalization have been done in NPs to enhance their effectiveness. Various processes
such as surface coating, capping, etc., have been employed by the researchers in the functionalization of ZnO NPs.264 For incidence, Ba-Abbad et al. reported during the
functionalization, the capping agents, the reactants ratio and pH have a great influence in the particle size and properties of the ZnO NPs.264 Chung et al. studied the functionalization of
ZnO NPs with ethylene glycol and the effect of this incorporation in the permeation and antifouling properties of PS membranes.265 The ZnO NPs are already highly hydrophilic and
have a high affinity towards water molecules. The hydrophilic surfactant EG
functionalization further enhanced the resultant nanocomposite membrane hydrophilicity.
This is mainly due to the hydroxyl group present in the ethylene glycol forming a hybrid with water molecules.254

sections.heading: 5.1. Silicon dioxide nanoparticles
sections.text:
Silicon dioxide NPs are considered to be more suitable in drinking water treatment
since they are less toxic to the environment compared to silver and copper NPs.266 Many
researchers have widely reported that silica has a significant effect in enhancing the performance of water treatment membranes.267,268 Apart from a nano-hydrophilic additive,
nano-silica has been considered to be an effective pore forming agent and has a tendency to
increase the number of surface pores rather than increase the size of already existing pores.266,269 By this way, there is a possibility for a higher amount of surface pore formations
which could eventually lower the fouling tendency of the membrane due to the low specific content imposed on individual pores.270 Recently, researchers have been working on the
modification of PVDF polymeric membrane with SiO2 NPs via various types of incorporation

Fernandes et al. reported that the PVDF polymer dope viscosity was increased by the
incorporation of fumed silica which facilitates the formation of a larger number of pores on the surface of the membrane.275 As a results, the surface structure of the composite membrane was greatly altered.275 As a consequence of high surface porosity, the membrane fouling property is significantly reduced and this eventually increases the membrane shelf life.276
However, at relatively high concentrations of silica, the high viscosity of the polymer dope
leads to a slower solvent non-solvent exchange rate and considerably reduces the overall surface porosity.277 Habibi et al. studied the water flux enhancement in PSf membrane with the addition and subsequent removal of silica NPs.278 While the addition of 1% nano-silica
increases the surface pore diameter, the subsequent removal results in an additional number
of pores and thereby increases the total number of surface pores and the overall porosity of the concern membrane.279 Mesoporous silica incorporated nanocomposite membranes were prepared by Zornoza et al.280, and H2/CH4 separation performances were tested. The authors reported that, the resultant nanocomposite membranes showed enhanced thermal and
mechanical stability and better separation properties than the pristine membranes due to the
addition of mesoporous silica. Synthesis and incorporation of mesoporous silica nanoparticles to improve the antifouling properties of PSf membrane was studied by Huang et al.277 The
added mesoporous silica migrates towards the top surface of the PES matrix during the phase
separation process in order to reduce the interfacial energy between the water bath and
polymer casting solution. An even distribution of silica NPs on the concern membrane’s top
surface, with increasing silica concentration, leads to the formation of inter-connected macrovoids in the bulk.281 Also, the formation of a polymer-poor phase in the nuclei during
phase inversion had more silica particles compared to the surrounding matrix. There is a
possibility for the migration of silica NPs from the blend solution to the nuclei of the polymer

the bulk and surface, respectively, thereby enhancing the membrane hydrophilicity and permeation properties.283 This phenomenon leads to the development of longer and broader
finger-like morphological structures in the composite membrane. However, a significant
suppression in the macrovoid formation was reported by Lalia et al. at relatively high silica NPs concentrations due to enhanced polymer dope viscosity.284 This leads to the formation of
more thick and dense membranes with reduced porosity. In addition, it has been widely
reported in the literature that SiO2 NPs has a tendency to enhance the thermal stability of the composite membrane since it forms a strong interaction/chemical bonding with the polymer matrix.285,286 Ahmad et al. reported that the incorporation of SiO2 NPs can reduce the fouling caused even by PSf membrane.287 Also, the pore enlargement issue in the PSf membrane
caused due to the agglomeration of SiO2 NPs at higher concentrations can be overcome with the addition of poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA).288
Commonly, metal oxide NPs are surface modified/functionalized mainly to improve
their dispersibility in solvents.289 This happens in such a way that the dispersants
deposited/coated on the NPs generate steric repulsive forces among the concern polymer chain matrices. As a consequence, this leads to better NPs dispersion.290 It was reported by
Yang et al. that surface functionalization is also helpful in enhancing the surface charge
which has a significant influence in improving the dispersion properties of the NPs in respective solvent mediums.291 Also, researchers have done comparative studies of the
dispersion ability of the functionalized and bare NPs in different solvents. They observed that
the bare NPs show only partial dispersion and settled as precipitate within 24 h whereas the

functionalized SiO2 NPs using a silane coupling agent and further decorated them with a polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) chain on the surface. The decorated PDMS migrates to the
surface of the nanoparticles and thereby enhances the stability of the nano-silica in the membrane matrix.295 The modification of PES membrane using poly(2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate) (PHEMA) grafted SiO2 NPs was done by Zhu et al.296 and reported that, at lower concentrations, the favorable effect of thermodynamic properties play a predominant
role. Beyond a certain concentration, the negative effect of solution viscosity limits the pore
forming and hydrophilicity properties of the PHEMA-SiO2 composite membrane. This is because even though there is no agglomeration and low dispersion issue due to surface
functionalization of nano-SiO2, at high PHEMA-SiO2 loading, the high viscous dope solution leads to the formation of relatively thick, less porous and compact membranes. As a result,
the permeation and hydrophilicity properties were reduced. Zhu et al. studied the
performance of PES membrane incorporated with poly(2-dimethylamino ethyl methacrylate)
(PDMAEMA) grafted SiO2 NPs (PSBMA) and reported that the antifouling properties of the resultant membranes were greatly enhanced with the PSBMA addition.296 This is due to the
zwitter-ionic sulfobetaine groups present in PSBMA which has a tendency to form a
hydration layer through electrostatic interaction thereby reducing the risk of membrane
surface fouling. A schematic representation of the antifouling and anti-biofouling properties of PES/PSBMA-SiO2 is given in Figure 11.296

sections.heading: 5.2 Zeolites
sections.text:
Zeolites are considered to be one of the safest environmentally friendly and cost-
effective hydrated aluminosilicate materials which possess outstanding ion-exchange and sorption properties for water treatment applications.300 Zeolites are categorized as cationic
exchangers since the presence of an additional negative charge on the surface of the zeolite
leads to the isomorphic replacement of silicon by aluminum in the basic structural units.301 Leo et al. reported that the negatively charged sites present in zeolites can be
counterbalanced when the proton causes the formation of Brønsted-acid sites, thereby increasing their separation performance in aqueous streams.302 The performance of zeolite

membranes in water treatment applications have been reported by various researchers using different kinds of membrane preparation techniques.303,304 The 3D pore networks present in
zeolite nanoparticles are super hydrophilic in nature and enhance the water permeation properties of the resultant membrane.305 Further, due to steric and Donnan exclusion, the zeolite membranes exhibit better selectivity during metal-ion separation experiments.302 The
most important advantage of zeolite-based membranes in water treatment is that of enhanced
hydrophilicity, which in turn, brings about improved contaminant removal efficiency from wastewater.306 Further, the most important bottleneck that arises in handling nanoparticle
incorporated membranes is dope solution viscosity enhancement at higher additive concentrations.307 However, Han et al. reported that this viscosity issue can be avoided in
zeolite nanoparticle loaded membranes when compared to inorganic nanofiller incorporated membranes.308 Also, when employed in dye removal applications, the zeolite modified
membranes exhibited excellent separation performance with improved water permeability due to the formation of smaller sized pores.309 The zeolite membranes have been reported to
result in better alcohol removal characteristics from water when tested with ethanol and butanol than that of polymeric membranes.310 Overall, the zeolite membranes are considered
to be a potential candidate for treating industrial waste water since these membranes
combine the advantages of zeolite nanofillers with polymeric membranes. In spite of several
advantages and a wide range of applications, the fabrication of defect-free zeolite
membranes with an appropriate thickness still remains a challenge. Also the relatively
expensive zeolite membrane fabrication techniques, required to bring about good water
permeability, further limits the industrial uses of zeolite membranes for water treatment applications.311 However, these membrane fabrication difficulties can be minimized by
altering the membrane preparation conditions such as using high operational temperature,
priming the nanoparticle surface before being used in membrane fabrication as well as

water permeability and foulant removal efficiency, needs more detailed investigation. Also,
further researches needs to be conducted that focuses on developing novel techniques which
can offer a clearer understanding of the actual transport mechanism involved during
filtration through zeolite membranes.
6. Summary
The hydrophilicity and separation performance of various nanomaterials incorporated
ultrafiltration membranes are listed in Tables 1, 2 and 3, separately. Different kinds of
methods such as physical blending, surface coating and in-situ immobilization, etc., have
been developed for modification of water treatment ultrafiltration membranes using a variety
of nanomaterials. These are discussed in detail, and their incorporation using physical
blending to modify the basic membrane properties is considered to be the best way to do this.
The reason for this is that this method doesn’t need any further steps during membrane
fabrication. Also, when compared to other surface modification techniques, the
nanocomposite membranes, with various nanoparticles incorporated via physical blending,
show improved performance in terms of hydrophilicity, permeation and antifouling. These
membranes possess superior nanoparticle stability in the nanocomposite membrane matrix.
Since the bio-toxicity of different nanomaterials has been considered as one of the crucial
factors to be addressed, the prolonged stability of nanomaterials fabricated via physical
blending is considered to be the most important advantages over other membrane
modification techniques. This indicates their favorable potential influence because of their
overall membrane characteristics versus other methods. It should be noted that beyond certain

percentage of nanoadditive concentration in nanocomposite membranes differs based on the
type of polymeric material and the nature and the chemical composition of nanoadditive used.
However, the agglomeration of nanoparticles in the membrane matrix can be minimized by
functionalizing/coating the nanoparticles with suitable materials. The synthesis and
incorporation of functionalized nanoparticles in UF membranes and their influence in
membrane overall performance are also reviewed in detail. Furthermore, regarding the
filtration mechanisms, it can be demonstrated that all types of nanocomposite membranes are
able to separate the target water pollutants via pore-size selection and electrostatic forces.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text:
In past few decades, the usage of membrane-based technologies for water treatment
applications has been utilized more often in practice because of the advantageous processes
versus other separation techniques. However, some limitations of conventional polymeric
membranes including their high hydrophobicity and fouling tendencies have led to the
incorporation of organic/inorganic fillers/pore formers in order to boost their overall
performance. More recently, the use of nano-sized particles as hydrophilic additives in the
base polymeric membrane matrix to fabricate nanocomposite membranes has attracted the
attention of scientists for water treatment applications. These applications improve the overall
hydrophilicity, antifouling properties, foulant separation efficiencies and mechanical/thermal
stabilities of the membranes. This article presents a brief review of the efforts made by
researchers thus far to enhance the overall performance of ultrafiltration membranes. In this
regard, various nano-materials have been synthesized using different techniques and
employed successfully for the process of wastewater treatment. This article particularly

investigates the role of carbon based (SWCNTs, MWCNTs), graphene based (GO, graphene
nanosheets, etc.), metal oxide NPs (TiO2, ZnO) and silicon based NPs (SiO2, Zeolites) in enhancing the permeation, separation and antifouling properties of polymeric membranes.
The different techniques involved in the modification of UF membranes using inorganic and
organic NPs such as surface coating, particle immobilization, physical blending etc. and their
influence in the morphological and separation properties were investigated and reported in
detail. Other than the mere removal of organic pollutants from wastewater, the
nanocomposite UF membranes were also widely employed in the removal of toxic metal ions
as well. Undoubtedly, these nano-materials have a significant effect in enhancing the desired
characteristics of polymeric membranes due to their high hydrophilicity, large surface area
and excellent thermal and mechanical stability. However, the most important challenge/risk
to overcome in using nanomaterial in this field is that the release of these nanomaterials into
the environment during the UF process and their accumulation in the environment can cause
serious health risks. The strategy of incorporation of low concentrations of nano-additives
can be a more pronounced way to minimize/mitigate the release/leaching of nano-fillers
during filtration experiments. Since a relatively small quantity can stick to the base polymer
matrix with a high level of stability. As a result, the effective adhesion of nanoparticles on the
membrane surface during immobilization and the high stability of nanoparticles during
physical blending or membrane bulk incorporation should be achieved during the membrane
preparation process. Hence, in future, efforts should be undertaken to achieve a no/minimal
leaching of the incorporated nanomaterial from the concerned polymer matrix. In this
manner, we can avoid the risk of serious health issues resulting from the presence of
nanomaterials in living organisms.
